prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 2
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: There's not a person in the world who hasn't heard of this famous great detective, whose deductions never fail to surprise.
Character 3
Name: Yujin Mikotoba
Description: A medical school professor at the Imperial Yumei University. He's an authority in forensic medicine, and Miss Susato's father.
Character 4
Name: Seishiro Jigoku
Description: The Minister of Foreign Affairs and a judge of the Supreme Court of Judicature in Japan. He's the man who acquitted me when I was once accused of murder.
Character 5
Name: Mael Stronghart
Description: The Lord Chief Justice, who wields absolute authority in judicial matters, including the appointment of lawyers. He's a thoroughly intimidating man.
Character 6
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: A prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey. Supposedly, the souls of those he prosecutes are eternally damned, one way or another.
Character 7
Name: Gina Lestrade
Description: A mostly reformed pickpocket who's now a self-appointed 'detective inspector'. She's really making waves in her new apprenticeship.
Character 8
Name: Evie Vigil
Description: A client who has engaged the services of Mr Sholmes. She has asked the great detective to help track down her missing husband.
Character 9
Name: Daley Vigil
Description: A man who's disappeared without a word to his family. He was the former chief warder of Barclay Prison.
Character 10
Name: Barry Caidin
Description: The governor of Barclay Prison. It seems he was good friends with Professor Mikotoba during the Japanese man's time in Britain as a visiting student.
Character 11
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: A murdered Scotland Yard inspector. He was stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 12
Name: Kazuma Asogi
Description: My best friend, who I had believed to be dead. He lost his memory somehow, but has now materialised as a prosecutor in the British courts.
Character 13
Name: Gossip
Description: A pedlar plying his trade on Fresno Street. He seems to make his money selling interesting items of news to passers-by.
Character 14
Name: Venus
Description: A pedlar plying her trade on Fresno Street. She seems to make her money selling meagre little fireworks to children.
Character 15
Name: Sandwich
Description: A mysterious 'signpost' who can be found on Fresno street. He looks familiar somehow...
Character 16
Name: Fabien de Rousseau
Description: The fraudster behind the Red-Headed League swindle, who was caught by Mr Sholmes. He derives from the French aristocracy, it seems.
Character 17
Name: Peppino de Rossi
Description: A lackey of de Rousseau and conspirator in the Red-Headed League swindle. The third son of a great Italian landowner.
Character 18
Name: Maria Gorey
Description: The daughter of Dr Sithe who's also a coroner like her mother. She carries out all the autopsy work on corpses.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Red-Headed League Article
Description: An advertisement from the newspaper that's entitled 'To the Red-Headed League'. It seems somewhat suspicious in nature.
Evidence 2
Name: Photograph of Mr Vigil
Description: A photographic print received from Mrs Vigil in order to aid with locating her missing husband. He appears to have no particularly distinctive facial features.
Evidence 3
Name: Letter of Introduction
Description: A note of introduction on our behalf from Professor Mikotoba to Governor Caidin. Hopefully now he'll be willing to talk to us. A note of introduction on our behalf from Professor Mikotoba to Governor Caidin. It's written on the back of a ticket for passage on a steamship.
Evidence 4
Name: Dismissal Notice
Description: The harsh reprimand incurred by Mr Vigil ten years ago that resulted in him losing his job as chief warder of Barclay Prison.
Evidence 5
Name: Red Hairpiece
Description: A flame-red wig found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. Presumably it belonged to Inspector Gregson...
Evidence 6
Name: Candelabrum
Description: A candelabrum from the wall of the room on Fresno Street where the inspector was found dead. The top of one of the candles appears to have been blown off.
Evidence 7
Name: Revolver
Description: The murder weapon that was found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. Probably best to avoid handling it.
Evidence 8
Name: Policeman Figurine
Description: A small and rather endearing model of a British policeman found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. A model of a British policeman found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. Giving it a twist causes a key-like shaft to pop out from the base.
Evidence 9
Name: Framed Photograph
Description: A photographic print of a smiling Mrs Vigil in her younger years. It was found on a desk at the scene of the crime.
Evidence 10
Name: Gregson's Photograph
Description: An old photographic print displayed rather prominently in Inspector Gregson's office, as if it was a treasured memory. An old photographic print displayed rather prominently in Inspector Gregson's office. The person on the left is Lord Klint van Zieks.
Evidence 11
Name: Autopsy Report
Description: Inspector Gregson's autopsy report, stating that death was instant, resulting from a bullet shot at close range. The autopsy report from the examination of Inspector Gregson's body. According to the coroner, Dr Gorey, an accurate estimation of the time of death is not possible.
Evidence 12
Name: Crime Scene Floor Plan
Description: A plan of the small room in the building of flats on Fresno Street where the body of the victim, Inspector Gregson, was found.
Evidence 13
Name: Noticeboard
Description: A free-standing noticeboard completely covered in notes and articles relating to victims of the Reaper of the Bailey. A free-standing noticeboard completely covered in notes and articles relating to victims of the Reaper. There is a bloody handprint on the back side.
Evidence 14
Name: Venus Firecracker
Description: The Venus Special firecracker consisting of one hundred smaller fireworks at sixpence each. What sort of bang could it make...? The Venus Special firecracker consisting of one hundred smaller fireworks at sixpence each. It goes off like a gunshot.
Evidence 15
Name: Photograph of the Victim
Description: A photographic print of the victim, Inspector Gregson. His body appears to be tightly curled up and there's a red hairpiece on his head.
Evidence 16
Name: Gregson's Pocket Watch
Description: Inspector Gregson's pocket watch that he wound without fail every single day. It's no longer ticking and the glass over the face is cracked. Inspector Gregson's pocket watch that he wound without fail every single day. Having wound it up, it's started ticking again.
Evidence 17
Name: Inspector's Identification
Description: The identification of a man claiming to be a detective inspector, confiscated by Mr de Rousseau and Mr de Rossi. Inspector Gregson's police identification. It's the official warrant card issued to him by Scotland Yard.
Evidence 18
Name: Commemorative Photograph
Description: A photograph taken in the foyer of the Great Waterloo Hotel on the morning of Professor Mikotoba and Judge Jigoku's arrival in London for the symposium.
Evidence 19
Name: The Asogi Papers
Description: The last will and testament of Genshin Asogi that Mr Vigil claims disappeared after the convict's execution. Apparently Mr Asogi described it as 'the only weapon I have left'. The last will and testament of Genshin Asogi that Mr Vigil claims disappeared after the convict's execution. It seems there was a third page to it.
Evidence 20
Name: Gregson's Trunk
Description: Inspector Gregson's metal travelling trunk that was removed from the scene, but subsequently recovered by Gina.
Evidence 21
Name: Passport
Description: A passport document that was in Inspector Gregson's possession. It was issued for travel to France the day before his body was discovered.
Evidence 22
Name: Klint's Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the final victim of the infamous Professor. The report was authored by Dr John H. Wilson. The report from the autopsy of the Professor's final victim. It's signed by Dr John H. Wilson who carried out the procedure, though Professor Mikotoba actually penned the report.
Evidence 23
Name: Iris's Lucky Charm
Description: A little doll of Mr Sholmes in hare form. I've been told to tug its ears if I run out of options in the trial today...
Evidence 24
Name: Great Sword 'Karuma'
Description: The illustrious blade passed down through generations of the Asogi clan. The prized sword's tip has a small piece missing.
Evidence 25
Name: Evacuation Drill Itinerary
Description: A notice about a practice evacuation to be carried out by the crew of the SS Grouse the night before the ship arrived in Dover. It was found in Judge Jigoku's cabin.
Evidence 26
Name: Small Component
Description: A small machine part that Mr Sholmes found in Judge Jigoku's cabin on the SS Grouse. A small machine part that Mr Sholmes found in Judge Jigoku's cabin on the SS Grouse. It's now clear that it's the missing 'crown' of Inspector Gregson's pocket watch. * (This update to the description is entirely optional, and can only be achieved by examining anywhere on this evidence, then the tip on Gregson's Pocket Watch before the former evidence is specifically presented in court. However, this method still occurs in Story Mode.)
Evidence 27
Name: Telegram from Japan
Description: A telegram from Inspector Hosonaga in Japan with details of the telegram he managed to locate by stealing into Judge Jigoku's office.
Evidence 28
Name: Mr Asogi's Ring
Description: A ring belonging to Genshin Asogi found in Lord Klint van Zieks's stomach during the autopsy. The claws clasping the gem look sharp enough to cause a very nasty scratch.
Evidence 29
Name: Klint van Zieks's Will
Description: The last will and testament of Lord Klint van Zieks that has been hidden inside the great sword Karuma for years. A trump card left behind by Genshin Asogi.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: It's true that Kazuma Asogi was assigned the assassination mission one year ago now.
Person: Jigoku
Testimony 1
Testimony: The target was Inspector T. Gregson. That was a condition of the British study tour.
Person: Jigoku
Testimony 2
Testimony: However...in the end something happened that meant the young man was unable to carry out his mission.
Person: Jigoku
Testimony 3
Testimony: On the evening in question, a member of the crew was on duty outside my cabin at all times.
Person: Jigoku
Testimony 4
Testimony: If there'd been a shot fired, the crewman would have heard it. So clearly I can't be involved.
Person: Jigoku

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Testimony 3 states that "On the evening in question, a member of the crew was on duty outside my cabin at all times." implying continuous supervision and awareness of activity near Judge Jigoku's cabin.

Evidence 25, the "Evacuation Drill Itinerary," indicates that there was a practice evacuation to be carried out by the crew of the SS Grouse the night before arriving in Dover. This suggests that the crew would have been engaged in a drill, which could mean less attention to guarding the cabin during the actual time of the supposed incident, potentially contradicting the assertion of continuous presence and supervision from testimony 3.

However, the contradiction is clearer with testimony 4: "If there'd been a shot fired, the crewman would have heard it. So clearly I can't be involved." This directly conflicts with the evidence that Inspector Gregson was shot (Evidence 11: Autopsy Report states death by bullet shot at close range) near or around the time in question, despite the supposed constant presence of a crew member and their auditory awareness.

So the contradiction is between:

Evidence 11: Autopsy Report indicating the victim died from a bullet shot at close range.

Testimony 4: Jigoku claiming if a shot had been fired, the crewman would have heard it, thus implying no shot fired.

Therefore, the evidence of a shot and death by bullet directly contradicts the testimony that no shot was fired because a crew member would have heard it.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: I had a guest waiting for me when I returned to my cabin after finishing my evening meal in the dining room.
Person: Jigoku
Testimony 1
Testimony: When I walked through the door, a mustachioed Englishman was there, foolishly waving a gun at me.
Person: Jigoku
Testimony 2
Testimony: I soon took care of him with an ippon seoi throw, though. He couldn't wait to run away after that.
Person: Jigoku
Testimony 3
Testimony: I imagine his watch was broken when I threw him over my shoulder. It has nothing to do with his murder.
Person: Jigoku
Testimony 4
Testimony: The inspector was clearly killed having returned to Britain. Because his body was found in London.
Person: Jigoku
Testimony 5
Testimony: There's no possible way I could have transported the victim's corpse back to Britain.
Person: Jigoku

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot: Testimony 3 states that "I imagine his watch was broken when I threw him over my shoulder. It has nothing to do with his murder." However, Evidence 16 describes "Gregson's Pocket Watch" as no longer ticking and the glass over the face is cracked, but after winding, it started ticking again. This suggests the watch was indeed broken (or at least stopped) around the time of the murder, implying that the damage to the watch may be relevant to the murder. This creates a contradiction between the testimony stating the broken watch is unrelated to the murder and the evidence suggesting the watch was tampered with or stopped at the time of death.

Description: A photograph taken in the foyer of the Great Waterloo Hotel on the morning of Professor Mikotoba and Judge Jigoku's arrival in London for the symposium.
Evidence 19
Name: The Asogi Papers
Description: The last will and testament of Genshin Asogi that Mr Vigil claims disappeared after the convict's execution. Apparently Mr Asogi described it as 'the only weapon I have left'. The last will and testament of Genshin Asogi that Mr Vigil claims disappeared after the convict's execution. It seems there was a third page to it.
Evidence 20
Name: Gregson's Trunk
Description: Inspector Gregson's metal travelling trunk that was removed from the scene, but subsequently recovered by Gina.
Evidence 21
Name: Passport
Description: A passport document that was in Inspector Gregson's possession. It was issued for travel to France the day before his body was discovered.
Evidence 22
Name: Klint's Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the final victim of the infamous Professor. The report was authored by Dr John H. Wilson. The report from the autopsy of the Professor's final victim. It's signed by Dr John H. Wilson who carried out the procedure, though Professor Mikotoba actually penned the report.
Evidence 23
Name: Iris's Lucky Charm
Description: A little doll of Mr Sholmes in hare form. I've been told to tug its ears if I run out of options in the trial today...
Evidence 24
Name: Great Sword 'Karuma'
Description: The illustrious blade passed down through generations of the Asogi clan. The prized sword's tip has a small piece missing.
Evidence 25
Name: Evacuation Drill Itinerary
Description: A notice about a practice evacuation to be carried out by the crew of the SS Grouse the night before the ship arrived in Dover. It was found in Judge Jigoku's cabin.
Evidence 26
Name: Small Component
Description: A small machine part that Mr Sholmes found in Judge Jigoku's cabin on the SS Grouse. A small machine part that Mr Sholmes found in Judge Jigoku's cabin on the SS Grouse. It's now clear that it's the missing 'crown' of Inspector Gregson's pocket watch. * (This update to the description is entirely optional, and can only be achieved by examining anywhere on this evidence, then the tip on Gregson's Pocket Watch before the former evidence is specifically presented in court. However, this method still occurs in Story Mode.)
Evidence 27
Name: Telegram from Japan
Description: A telegram from Inspector Hosonaga in Japan with details of the telegram he managed to locate by stealing into Judge Jigoku's office.
Evidence 28
Name: Mr Asogi's Ring
Description: A ring belonging to Genshin Asogi found in Lord Klint van Zieks's stomach during the autopsy. The claws clasping the gem look sharp enough to cause a very nasty scratch.
Evidence 29
Name: Klint van Zieks's Will
Description: The last will and testament of Lord Klint van Zieks that has been hidden inside the great sword Karuma for years. A trump card left behind by Genshin Asogi.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: I've never taken the life of another. Nor have I instructed another to kill.
Person: Van Zieks
Testimony 1
Testimony: I've been investigating the truth behind the Reaper for years. And I was aware of Gregson's involvement.
Person: Van Zieks
Testimony 2
Testimony: That's the reason why I went to Fresno Street that day, and how I came to discover the body.
Person: Van Zieks
Testimony 3
Testimony: The point is, no common thread exists between myself, Gregson and Dr Wilson.
Person: Van Zieks
Testimony 4
Testimony: Clearly, therefore, there's no reason to suspect me of being behind the assassin exchange.
Person: Van Zieks

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot: Evidence 10 is "Gregson's Photograph," which shows Lord Klint van Zieks and Inspector Gregson together, suggesting some connection between them. However, Testimony 3 by Van Zieks claims, "The point is, no common thread exists between myself, Gregson and Dr Wilson," denying any connection. This contradicts the photographic evidence clearly showing a relationship or at least an acquaintance between Van Zieks and Gregson.

prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Susato Mikotoba
Description: A judicial assistant sent to Britain on a study tour. She's the epitome of a refined Japanese lady and a huge help to me always.
Character 1
Name: Iris Wilson
Description: An extraordinary young girl who lives with Mr Sholmes. She has a degree in medicine and is the author of a popular series of short stories.
Character 2
Name: Herlock Sholmes
Description: There's not a person in the world who hasn't heard of this famous great detective, whose deductions never fail to surprise.
Character 3
Name: Yujin Mikotoba
Description: A medical school professor at the Imperial Yumei University. He's an authority in forensic medicine, and Miss Susato's father.
Character 4
Name: Seishiro Jigoku
Description: The Minister of Foreign Affairs and a judge of the Supreme Court of Judicature in Japan. He's the man who acquitted me when I was once accused of murder.
Character 5
Name: Mael Stronghart
Description: The Lord Chief Justice, who wields absolute authority in judicial matters, including the appointment of lawyers. He's a thoroughly intimidating man.
Character 6
Name: Barok van Zieks
Description: A prosecutor known as the Reaper of the Bailey. Supposedly, the souls of those he prosecutes are eternally damned, one way or another.
Character 7
Name: Gina Lestrade
Description: A mostly reformed pickpocket who's now a self-appointed 'detective inspector'. She's really making waves in her new apprenticeship.
Character 8
Name: Evie Vigil
Description: A client who has engaged the services of Mr Sholmes. She has asked the great detective to help track down her missing husband.
Character 9
Name: Daley Vigil
Description: A man who's disappeared without a word to his family. He was the former chief warder of Barclay Prison.
Character 10
Name: Barry Caidin
Description: The governor of Barclay Prison. It seems he was good friends with Professor Mikotoba during the Japanese man's time in Britain as a visiting student.
Character 11
Name: Tobias Gregson
Description: A murdered Scotland Yard inspector. He was stern and single-minded in his approach, and a great lover of fish and chips.
Character 12
Name: Kazuma Asogi
Description: My best friend, who I had believed to be dead. He lost his memory somehow, but has now materialised as a prosecutor in the British courts.
Character 13
Name: Gossip
Description: A pedlar plying his trade on Fresno Street. He seems to make his money selling interesting items of news to passers-by.
Character 14
Name: Venus
Description: A pedlar plying her trade on Fresno Street. She seems to make her money selling meagre little fireworks to children.
Character 15
Name: Sandwich
Description: A mysterious 'signpost' who can be found on Fresno street. He looks familiar somehow...
Character 16
Name: Fabien de Rousseau
Description: The fraudster behind the Red-Headed League swindle, who was caught by Mr Sholmes. He derives from the French aristocracy, it seems.
Character 17
Name: Peppino de Rossi
Description: A lackey of de Rousseau and conspirator in the Red-Headed League swindle. The third son of a great Italian landowner.
Character 18
Name: Maria Gorey
Description: The daughter of Dr Sithe who's also a coroner like her mother. She carries out all the autopsy work on corpses.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Red-Headed League Article
Description: An advertisement from the newspaper that's entitled 'To the Red-Headed League'. It seems somewhat suspicious in nature.
Evidence 2
Name: Photograph of Mr Vigil
Description: A photographic print received from Mrs Vigil in order to aid with locating her missing husband. He appears to have no particularly distinctive facial features.
Evidence 3
Name: Letter of Introduction
Description: A note of introduction on our behalf from Professor Mikotoba to Governor Caidin. Hopefully now he'll be willing to talk to us. A note of introduction on our behalf from Professor Mikotoba to Governor Caidin. It's written on the back of a ticket for passage on a steamship.
Evidence 4
Name: Dismissal Notice
Description: The harsh reprimand incurred by Mr Vigil ten years ago that resulted in him losing his job as chief warder of Barclay Prison.
Evidence 5
Name: Red Hairpiece
Description: A flame-red wig found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. Presumably it belonged to Inspector Gregson...
Evidence 6
Name: Candelabrum
Description: A candelabrum from the wall of the room on Fresno Street where the inspector was found dead. The top of one of the candles appears to have been blown off.
Evidence 7
Name: Revolver
Description: The murder weapon that was found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. Probably best to avoid handling it.
Evidence 8
Name: Policeman Figurine
Description: A small and rather endearing model of a British policeman found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. A model of a British policeman found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. Giving it a twist causes a key-like shaft to pop out from the base.
Evidence 9
Name: Framed Photograph
Description: A photographic print of a smiling Mrs Vigil in her younger years. It was found on a desk at the scene of the crime.
Evidence 10
Name: Gregson's Photograph
Description: An old photographic print displayed rather prominently in Inspector Gregson's office, as if it was a treasured memory. An old photographic print displayed rather prominently in Inspector Gregson's office. The person on the left is Lord Klint van Zieks.
Evidence 11
Name: Autopsy Report
Description: Inspector Gregson's autopsy report, stating that death was instant, resulting from a bullet shot at close range. The autopsy report from the examination of Inspector Gregson's body. According to the coroner, Dr Gorey, an accurate estimation of the time of death is not possible.
Evidence 12
Name: Crime Scene Floor Plan
Description: A plan of the small room in the building of flats on Fresno Street where the body of the victim, Inspector Gregson, was found.
Evidence 13
Name: Noticeboard
Description: A free-standing noticeboard completely covered in notes and articles relating to victims of the Reaper of the Bailey. A free-standing noticeboard completely covered in notes and articles relating to victims of the Reaper. There is a bloody handprint on the back side.
Evidence 14
Name: Venus Firecracker
Description: The Venus Special firecracker consisting of one hundred smaller fireworks at sixpence each. What sort of bang could it make...? The Venus Special firecracker consisting of one hundred smaller fireworks at sixpence each. It goes off like a gunshot.
Evidence 15
Name: Photograph of the Victim
Description: A photographic print of the victim, Inspector Gregson. His body appears to be tightly curled up and there's a red hairpiece on his head.
Evidence 16

Description: Inspector Gregson's pocket watch that he wound without fail every single day. It's no longer ticking and the glass over the face is cracked. Inspector Gregson's pocket watch that he wound without fail every single day. Having wound it up, it's started ticking again.

Description: The identification of a man claiming to be a detective inspector, confiscated by Mr de Rousseau and Mr de Rossi. Inspector Gregson's police identification. It's the official warrant card issued to him by Scotland Yard.

Name: Mr Asogi's Ring
Description: A ring belonging to Genshin Asogi found in Lord Klint van Zieks's stomach during the autopsy. The claws clasping the gem look sharp enough to cause a very nasty scratch.

Name: Klint van Zieks's Will
Description: The last will and testament of Lord Klint van Zieks that has been hidden inside the great sword Karuma for years. A trump card left behind by Genshin Asogi.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: From my own observations, I couldn't say there was any indication of the autopsy results having been fabricated.
Person: Mikotoba
Testimony 1
Testimony: Death resulted from a wound made by a Western-style sword transfixing the heart. That I found a little strange.
Person: Mikotoba
Testimony 2
Testimony: There were no other signs of internal injury. Nothing questionable at all.
Person: Gorey
Testimony 3
Testimony: It was just that beautiful but dangerous piece of evidence removed from the man's stomach.
Person: Gorey
Testimony 4
Testimony: Presumed to have been swallowed by the victim as a way of posthumously identifying his assailant.
Person: Van Zieks

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Evidence 3 is a Letter of Introduction from Professor Mikotoba to Governor Caidin mentioning a note of introduction to facilitate communication. However, there is no direct contradictory testimony associated with this evidence in the provided data.

Evidence 11 is Inspector Gregson's autopsy report stating death was instant from a close-range bullet shot but the coroner Dr. Gorey states accurate estimation of time of death is not possible (no contradiction here).

Evidence 1 is a suspicious advertisement "To the Red-Headed League," with no direct contradicting testimony.

Evidence 28 is Mr Asogi's Ring found in Lord Klint van Zieks's stomach during autopsy with sharp claws capable of causing a nasty scratch. Testimony 3 by Gorey mentions a beautiful but dangerous piece of evidence removed from the man's stomach. This matches and is supportive.

Testimony 1 by Mikotoba states that death resulted from a wound made by a Western-style sword transfixing the heart which is strange.

Testimony 2 by Gorey states no other signs of internal injury.

Evidence 22 is Klint's autopsy report mentioning the final victim of the Professor (Klint van Zieks), with report signed by Dr John H. Wilson but penned by Mikotoba.

Testimony 0 (Mikotoba) states no indication that the autopsy results were fabricated.

Testimony 4 by Van Zieks states it was "presumed to have been swallowed by the victim" as a way to identify assailant, referencing the ring.

Hence the contradiction can be found between:

- Testimony 1 (Mikotoba: Death resulted from a wound made by a Western-style sword transfixing the heart, a little strange)

- Testimony 2 (Gorey: There were no other signs of internal injury. Nothing questionable at all.)

Given that a wound transfixing the heart is an internal injury, Gorey's testimony stating there were no other signs of internal injury contradicts Mikotoba's statement.

Therefore, the evidence that matches this contradiction would be Evidence 22: Klint's Autopsy Report, which would record details about the wound.

Testimony 0
Testimony: It was the day that Japanese jock was found guilty. The directive came from the Prosecutor's Office.

Testimony 1
Testimony: I assigned the convict to the chief warder Vigil here, and put the plan into action behind the scenes.
Person: Caidin
Testimony 2
Testimony: I was responsible for Asogi right up until the night of his execution. But I knew nothing of any plot...
Person: Vigil
Testimony 3
Testimony: I dinnae ken if there were some negotiations between the convict and the Prosecutor's Office.
Person: Caidin
Testimony 4
Testimony: All I did was carry oot my duty! For Her Majesty's great British Empire!
Person: Caidin
Testimony 5
Testimony: It seems to me that the Japanese fella did'nae have nothin' to bargain with.
Person: Caidin

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot: The contradiction lies between Evidence 4 (Dismissal Notice) and Testimony 2 (Vigil's statement). The Dismissal Notice is the harsh reprimand that resulted in Mr. Vigil losing his job as chief warder of Barclay Prison. This evidence implies that Vigil was involved or responsible for some misconduct related to the convict. However, in Testimony 2, Vigil claims that he knew nothing of any plot related to Asogi and asserts his innocence or ignorance, which contrasts with the severity implied by the dismissal.

Description: A pedlar plying her trade on Fresno Street. She seems to make her money selling meagre little fireworks to children.
Character 15
Name: Sandwich
Description: A mysterious 'signpost' who can be found on Fresno street. He looks familiar somehow...
Character 16
Name: Fabien de Rousseau
Description: The fraudster behind the Red-Headed League swindle, who was caught by Mr Sholmes. He derives from the French aristocracy, it seems.
Character 17
Name: Peppino de Rossi
Description: A lackey of de Rousseau and conspirator in the Red-Headed League swindle. The third son of a great Italian landowner.
Character 18
Name: Maria Gorey
Description: The daughter of Dr Sithe who's also a coroner like her mother. She carries out all the autopsy work on corpses.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Armband
Description: An armband I inherited from Kazuma. It identifies the wearer as a defence lawyer throughout the Empire of Japan.
Evidence 1
Name: Red-Headed League Article
Description: An advertisement from the newspaper that's entitled 'To the Red-Headed League'. It seems somewhat suspicious in nature.
Evidence 2
Name: Photograph of Mr Vigil
Description: A photographic print received from Mrs Vigil in order to aid with locating her missing husband. He appears to have no particularly distinctive facial features.
Evidence 3
Name: Letter of Introduction
Description: A note of introduction on our behalf from Professor Mikotoba to Governor Caidin. Hopefully now he'll be willing to talk to us. A note of introduction on our behalf from Professor Mikotoba to Governor Caidin. It's written on the back of a ticket for passage on a steamship.
Evidence 4
Name: Dismissal Notice
Description: The harsh reprimand incurred by Mr Vigil ten years ago that resulted in him losing his job as chief warder of Barclay Prison.
Evidence 5
Name: Red Hairpiece
Description: A flame-red wig found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. Presumably it belonged to Inspector Gregson...
Evidence 6
Name: Candelabrum
Description: A candelabrum from the wall of the room on Fresno Street where the inspector was found dead. The top of one of the candles appears to have been blown off.
Evidence 7
Name: Revolver
Description: The murder weapon that was found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. Probably best to avoid handling it.
Evidence 8
Name: Policeman Figurine
Description: A small and rather endearing model of a British policeman found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. A model of a British policeman found at the scene of the crime on Fresno Street. Giving it a twist causes a key-like shaft to pop out from the base.
Evidence 9
Name: Framed Photograph
Description: A photographic print of a smiling Mrs Vigil in her younger years. It was found on a desk at the scene of the crime.
Evidence 10
Name: Gregson's Photograph
Description: An old photographic print displayed rather prominently in Inspector Gregson's office, as if it was a treasured memory. An old photographic print displayed rather prominently in Inspector Gregson's office. The person on the left is Lord Klint van Zieks.
Evidence 11
Name: Autopsy Report
Description: Inspector Gregson's autopsy report, stating that death was instant, resulting from a bullet shot at close range. The autopsy report from the examination of Inspector Gregson's body. According to the coroner, Dr Gorey, an accurate estimation of the time of death is not possible.
Evidence 12
Name: Crime Scene Floor Plan
Description: A plan of the small room in the building of flats on Fresno Street where the body of the victim, Inspector Gregson, was found.
Evidence 13
Name: Noticeboard
Description: A free-standing noticeboard completely covered in notes and articles relating to victims of the Reaper of the Bailey. A free-standing noticeboard completely covered in notes and articles relating to victims of the Reaper. There is a bloody handprint on the back side.
Evidence 14
Name: Venus Firecracker
Description: The Venus Special firecracker consisting of one hundred smaller fireworks at sixpence each. What sort of bang could it make...? The Venus Special firecracker consisting of one hundred smaller fireworks at sixpence each. It goes off like a gunshot.
Evidence 15
Name: Photograph of the Victim
Description: A photographic print of the victim, Inspector Gregson. His body appears to be tightly curled up and there's a red hairpiece on his head.
Evidence 16
Name: Gregson's Pocket Watch
Description: Inspector Gregson's pocket watch that he wound without fail every single day. It's no longer ticking and the glass over the face is cracked. Inspector Gregson's pocket watch that he wound without fail every single day. Having wound it up, it's started ticking again.
Evidence 17
Name: Inspector's Identification
Description: The identification of a man claiming to be a detective inspector, confiscated by Mr de Rousseau and Mr de Rossi. Inspector Gregson's police identification. It's the official warrant card issued to him by Scotland Yard.
Evidence 18
Name: Commemorative Photograph
Description: A photograph taken in the foyer of the Great Waterloo Hotel on the morning of Professor Mikotoba and Judge Jigoku's arrival in London for the symposium.
Evidence 19
Name: The Asogi Papers
Description: The last will and testament of Genshin Asogi that Mr Vigil claims disappeared after the convict's execution. Apparently Mr Asogi described it as 'the only weapon I have left'. The last will and testament of Genshin Asogi that Mr Vigil claims disappeared after the convict's execution. It seems there was a third page to it.
Evidence 20
Name: Gregson's Trunk
Description: Inspector Gregson's metal travelling trunk that was removed from the scene, but subsequently recovered by Gina.
Evidence 21
Name: Passport
Description: A passport document that was in Inspector Gregson's possession. It was issued for travel to France the day before his body was discovered.
Evidence 22
Name: Klint's Autopsy Report
Description: The autopsy report of the final victim of the infamous Professor. The report was authored by Dr John H. Wilson. The report from the autopsy of the Professor's final victim. It's signed by Dr John H. Wilson who carried out the procedure, though Professor Mikotoba actually penned the report.
Evidence 23
Name: Iris's Lucky Charm
Description: A little doll of Mr Sholmes in hare form. I've been told to tug its ears if I run out of options in the trial today...
Evidence 24
Name: Great Sword 'Karuma'
Description: The illustrious blade passed down through generations of the Asogi clan. The prized sword's tip has a small piece missing.
Evidence 25
Name: Evacuation Drill Itinerary
Description: A notice about a practice evacuation to be carried out by the crew of the SS Grouse the night before the ship arrived in Dover. It was found in Judge Jigoku's cabin.
Evidence 26
Name: Small Component
Description: A small machine part that Mr Sholmes found in Judge Jigoku's cabin on the SS Grouse. A small machine part that Mr Sholmes found in Judge Jigoku's cabin on the SS Grouse. It's now clear that it's the missing 'crown' of Inspector Gregson's pocket watch. * (This update to the description is entirely optional, and can only be achieved by examining anywhere on this evidence, then the tip on Gregson's Pocket Watch before the former evidence is specifically presented in court. However, this method still occurs in Story Mode.)
Evidence 27
Name: Telegram from Japan
Description: A telegram from Inspector Hosonaga in Japan with details of the telegram he managed to locate by stealing into Judge Jigoku's office.
Evidence 28
Name: Mr Asogi's Ring
Description: A ring belonging to Genshin Asogi found in Lord Klint van Zieks's stomach during the autopsy. The claws clasping the gem look sharp enough to cause a very nasty scratch.
Evidence 29
Name: Klint van Zieks's Will
Description: The last will and testament of Lord Klint van Zieks that has been hidden inside the great sword Karuma for years. A trump card left behind by Genshin Asogi.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: As the warder responsible for condemned convicts, I attended to Mr Asogi and kept watch over his cell.
Person: Vigil
Testimony 1
Testimony: The night after he was found guilty in court, he was doing something with that will in his cell!
Person: Vigil
Testimony 2
Testimony: We turned the cell inside out looking for it after the execution, but to no avail.
Person: Vigil
Testimony 3
Testimony: I only found oot about the Asogi Papers when a directive came tellin' me to impound them.
Person: Caidin
Testimony 4
Testimony: The document was in the folds of the fella's robe that was left in his cell. A 'kimono', I think it's called.
Person: Caidin
Testimony 5
Testimony: As I remember it, the document was written in scarlet ink, but...perhaps I'm mistaken.
Person: Vigil

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Testimony 1 states that "[Asogi] was doing something with that will in his cell" the night after he was found guilty, implying the will was physically present in Asogi's cell after the guilty verdict. However, Testimony 3 says, "I only found out about the Asogi Papers when a directive came telling me to impound them," suggesting that the prosecutor (Caidin) did not know about the will initially and that it was taken into custody only after a directive. This might indicate conflicting knowledge about the will's location after the verdict.

Moreover, Evidence 2 (Photograph of Mr Vigil) doesn't directly contradict with testimonies. Evidence 19 (The Asogi Papers) show the will disappeared after execution; Vigil (Testimony 2) says "We turned the cell inside out looking for it...but to no avail" which matches this absence.

None of the testimonies conflict with the evidence outright here.

However, Testimony 4 says "The document was in the folds of the fella's robe...a kimono" which suggests that the will was indeed found in the robe. But Vigil in Testimony 2 says "We turned the cell inside out looking for it after the execution, but to no avail," indicating they could not find the document.

This is a direct contradiction between:

Testimony 2: The will was not found after the execution despite searching.

Testimony 4: The will was in the folds of the robe left in the cell.

The related evidence is Evidence 19 (The Asogi Papers) that says the will disappeared after the convict's execution, indicating that no one found it after.

Therefore, the contradiction is between Testimony 2 (Vigil) claiming they did not find the will after searching the cell, and Testimony 4 (Caidin) claiming the document was found in the folds of the robe left in his cell.

But the prompt says to output one pair of evidence and testimony that contradict.

Evidence 19 states the will disappeared after execution, supporting Testimony 2.

Testimony 4 contradicts this by saying "The document was in the folds of the robe...left in his cell."

So, Evidence 19 and Testimony 4 contradict each other.
